In 2014, Smith (2018) noted that naive deployment of Stratospheric Aerosol Injection (SAI) can produce significant regional climatic effects in areas such as India and West Africa (Ricke, 2010). Without regulation, countries like China, Russia, or the US could unilaterally decide to alter their climates and disrupt the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), which affects the monsoon over India, as a byproduct. If geoengineering is stopped before the anthropogenic radiative forcing it aims to compensate for has decreased, termination effects with rapid warming would occur, leading to intergenerational injustice (Jones, 2013). Understanding how SAI can be optimized and how to respond to rogue injections is crucial for geostrategic reasons (Yu, 2015). This paper argues that optimal SAI control can be characterized as a high-dimensional Markov Decision Process (MDP) (Bellman, 1957). This motivates the use of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) (Mnih, 2015) to automatically discover non-trivial, and potentially time-varying, optimal injection policies or identify catastrophic ones. To overcome the inherent sample inefficiency of DRL, we propose emulating a Global Circulation Model (GCM) using deep learning techniques.

To our knowledge, this is the first proposed application of deep reinforcement learning to the climate sciences. 

2. Related work

General Circulation Models (GCMs), which simulate the Earth's climate on a global scale, are computationally intensive. Simple statistical methods are commonly used to estimate climate responses to slow forcings (Castruccio, 2013). Recent advances in deep learning have led to successful emulation attempts of full GCMs for weather prediction (Düben, 2018) and sub-grid scale processes (Brenowitz, 2018; Rasp, 2018), including precipitation (O’Gorman, 2018). This suggests that emulating the response of regional variables, such as precipitation and surface temperature, to aerosol injection forcings may now be feasible.

Investigation of optimal SAI control within the climate community is currently limited to low-dimensional injection pattern parameterizations (Ban-Weiss & Caldeira, 2010) or manual grid searches over edge cases of interest (Jackson, 2015). Even in simple settings, regional climate response has been shown to be sensitive to the choice of SAI policy (MacMartin, 2013). Additionally, super-regional impacts on El Niño/Southern Oscillation have been demonstrated (Gabriel, 2015). This suggests that climate response to SAI is sensitive enough to warrant a high-dimensional treatment. Altering the injection altitude, latitude, season, or particle type – possibly using specially engineered photophoretic nanoparticles (Keith, 2010) – may provide the ability to tailor fine-grained SAI. However, stratospheric aerosol models have substantially different responses to identical injection strategies (Pitari, 2014), indicating that directly simulating the implications of these strategies and the range of aerosol distributions that can be achieved requires further model development.

3. GCM emulation

We use HadCM3 (Gordon, 2000) to simulate the climate response to SAI, as it is the first GCM that does not require flux adjustments to avoid large-scale climate drift. Additionally, HadCM3 is still used as a baseline model for IPCC reports (IPCC, 2013). The radiative forcing of sulfate aerosols is emulated in HadCM3 by adjusting the aerosol optical depth (AOD) in the lower stratosphere, with a larger AOD corresponding to a larger sulfate aerosol concentration. Predominantly zonal winds in the stratosphere are assumed to keep aerosol optical depth zonally uniform to first order, so it is prescribed for each of the model's 73 latitude bands. We also assume that the aerosol optical depth is uniform in the vertical direction.
